perturbation.original_text: i-Escrow shall within two (2) weeks make any overdue payments disclosed by the audit.
perturbation.changed_text: i-Escrow shall within six (6) months make any overdue payments disclosed by the audit.
perturbation.explanation: California law requires that discrepancies found in audits, especially those related to payments, should be resolved promptly. Extending the payment deadline to six months contradicts the reasonable timeframe expected under California law and business practices, potentially leading to legal challenges regarding the delayed payment.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California contract law and general principles of good faith and fair dealing.

perturbation.original_text: Upon expiration or termination of this Agreement, within fourteen (14) days of the other party's request, each party will return all Confidential Information and other deliverables to the requesting party.
perturbation.changed_text: Upon expiration or termination of this Agreement, within ninety (90) days of the other party's request, each party will return all Confidential Information and other deliverables to the requesting party.
perturbation.explanation: In California, Trade Secret law requires that confidentiality be maintained through reasonable means. Extending the return of confidential information to 90 days after termination is not a reasonable timeframe. This delay increases the risk of misappropriation and weakens the trade secret protections, thereby conflicting with California law. California's Uniform Trade Secrets Act (CUTSA) requires reasonable measures to protect trade secrets, and delaying the return of confidential information for 90 days compromises this protection.

perturbation.original_text: A party wishing to renew this Agreement shall give the other party notice thereof no less than thirty (30) days before the expiration of the term then in effect.
perturbation.changed_text: A party wishing to renew this Agreement shall give the other party notice thereof no less than five (5) days before the expiration of the term then in effect.
perturbation.explanation: In California, the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing requires parties to a contract to act reasonably and honestly in their dealings with each other. Providing only a five-day notice period for renewal is insufficient time for the other party to adequately assess and respond, potentially leading to a disadvantageous outcome. This conflicts with the expectation of reasonable notice required by California contract law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California contract law related to good faith and fair dealing.
